title: WCG Inclusion Group Analysis
text:
Preface
This is a Quarto book.
To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.

title: Exploratory Analysis
text: This section documents the exploratory analysis of survey data. The purpose of this analysis is to understand the data, identify potential issues to address in the main analysis, and generate insights that may inform the research questions and hypotheses. Findings presented in this section are preliminary, and are subject to change as the data pipeline and analysis methodology are refined.

title: 1  Client Survey
text:
1.1 Preliminary Notes






Data Quality Issues



We observe some suspicious patterns in the data that are currently pending a more detailed investigation. These findings should be taken with more grains of salt than advised in the section introduction.



What we see in the data is a broad pattern of low satisfaction with employment services
If we take the responses at face value, they paint a picture of a system that troubling portions of its clients neither understand, feel understood by, trust, nor find effective
At a glance, we see that newcomers, youth, and Indigenous clients have particularly less positive experiences

title: 1  Client Survey
1  Client Survey
text:
1.3 Employment Services Client Characteristics

1.3.1 Inclusion Group Representation
Table 1.2 shows the representation of inclusion groups among client survey respondents.


Code
dplt_client_ig <- d_long_raw |>
    filter(engage_reached) |>
    group_by(inclusion_group_label) |>
    summarize(
        N = n(),
        n = sum(ig_member),
        p = n / N
    ) |>
    mutate(
        pn = glue::glue("{scales::percent(p, accuracy = 1)} ({n}/{N})")
    ) 

dplt_client_ig |>
    select(inclusion_group_label, sample_representation = pn) |>
    arrange(inclusion_group_label) |>
    gt() |>
    gtExtras::gt_theme_538() |>
    tab_source_note(
        source_note = dl_button(dplt_client_ig, "xp-client-igo")
    ) |> 
    cols_align(columns = c(sample_representation), align = "right")






Table 1.2:  Inclusion Group Representation Among ES Recipients in Client
Survey

Figure 1.4 shows the representation of each pair of inclusion groups among client survey respondents. Pairwise, the most common intersections we see are racialized newcomers, newcomers receiving social assistance, racialized francopohones, and francophone newcomers.


Code
dplt_ig_int <- d_long_raw |>
    filter(engage_reached) |>
    filter(ig_short != "[Z]") |> 
    select(response_id, ig_x = ig_short, val_x = ig_member) |> 
    filter(!is.na(val_x)) %>%
    left_join(
        rename(., ig_y = ig_x, val_y = val_x),
        by = "response_id",
        relationship = "many-to-many"
    ) |>
    group_by(ig_x, ig_y) |>
    summarize(
        N = n(),
        n = sum(val_x * val_y),
        p = mean(val_x * val_y)
    )


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'ig_x'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


Code
dplt_ig_int |>
    ggplot(aes(ig_x, ig_y, fill = p)) +
    geom_tile() +
    geom_label(aes(label = scales::percent(p, accuracy = 1)), color = "black", fill = "grey90", size = 10) +
    scale_fill_viridis_c() +
    theme_blueprint(base_size = 14)





Figure 1.4: Inclusion Group Intersections in Client Survey






1.3.2 Demographics
?tbl-xp-client-key-demos summarizes gender, parenthood, and age: the demographic characteristics included in the client survey but not reflected in the inclusion group indicator variables.


Code
tbl_key_demos <- d_long |>
    filter(engage_reached) |>
    group_by(inclusion_group_label) |>
    summarize(
        p_woman_plus = mean(demo_gender != "Man", na.rm = TRUE),
        p_parent = mean(demo_parent, na.rm = TRUE),
        mean_age = mean(demo_age, na.rm = TRUE),
        age_dist = list(demo_age),
    ) |> 
    arrange(inclusion_group_label)

reactable(
    tbl_key_demos,
    columns = list(
        p_woman_plus = colDef(
            cell = function(value) {
                scales::percent(value, accuracy = 1)
            }
        ),
        p_parent = colDef(
            cell = function(value) {
                scales::percent(value, accuracy = 1)
            }
        ),
        mean_age = colDef(
            cell = function(value) {
                round(value, 1)
            }
        ),
        age_dist = colDef(
            cell = function(values) {
                sparkline(
                    values,
                    type = "box",
                    chartRangeMin = min(d$demo_age, na.rm = TRUE),
                    chartRangeMax = max(d$demo_age, na.rm = TRUE)
                )
            }
        )
    )
)



?(caption)












1.3.3 Education
Figure 1.5 shows the education level of client survey respondents by inclusion group. At each level of education, the split between domestic and international education is shown in the fill colour.


Code
tbl_educ <- d_long |>
    filter(
        !is.na(demo_education),
        !is.na(demo_educ_domestic),
        engage_reached
    ) |>
    mutate(
        demo_educ_domestic = fct_rev(demo_educ_domestic)
    ) |>
    group_by(inclusion_group_label = ig_short, demo_education, demo_educ_domestic) |>
    summarize(
        n = n(),
        .groups = "drop_last"
    ) |>
    group_by(inclusion_group_label) |>
    mutate(
        p = n / sum(n)
    )

tbl_educ |>
    ggplot(aes(p, demo_education, fill = demo_educ_domestic)) +
    geom_col(position = "stack") +
    facet_wrap(~inclusion_group_label, ncol = 2) +
    scale_fill_blueprint(discrete = TRUE, type = "bipolar", option = "blue_green") +
    theme_blueprint(base_size = 12, grid = "Xx") +
    scale_x_continuous(
        labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1),
        limits = c(0, .5),
        expand = c(0, 0)
    )





Figure 1.5: Education Level of Client Survey Respondents by Inclusion Group




Figure 1.6 is based on the same data as Figure 1.5, but rather than showing the proportion of respondents at each level of education, it shows the proportion of respondents who have achieved at least each level of education.


Code
tbl_educ_ecdf <- tbl_educ |>
    arrange(desc(demo_education)) |>
    group_by(inclusion_group_label, demo_educ_domestic) |>
    mutate(
        ecdf = cumsum(p)
    )


tbl_educ_ecdf |>
    ggplot(aes(ecdf, demo_education, fill = demo_educ_domestic)) +
    geom_col(position = "stack") +
    facet_wrap(~inclusion_group_label, ncol = 2) +
    scale_fill_blueprint(discrete = TRUE, type = "bipolar", option = "blue_green") +
    theme_blueprint(base_size = 12, grid = "Xx") +
    scale_x_continuous(
        labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1),
        limits = c(0, 1),
        expand = c(0, 0)
    )





Figure 1.6: Education Achievement of Client Survey Respondents by Inclusion Group






1.3.4 Labour Force Status
?tbl-xp-client-es-lfs shows the labour force status of client survey respondents by inclusion group. The employment rate is the proportion of respondents who are employed, the enrollment rate is the proportion of respondents who are enrolled in education, and the NEET rate is the proportion of respondents who are not in employment, education, or training. The median annualized earnings are shown alongside the distribution of annualized earnings, visualized as a box plot for each inclusion group.


Code
tbl_emp <- d_long |>
    mutate(lfs_neet = !(lfs_employed | lfs_educ_enrolled)) |>
    filter(engage_reached) |>
    group_by(inclusion_group_label) |>
    summarize(
        employment_rate = mean(lfs_employed, na.rm = TRUE),
        enrollment_rate = mean(lfs_educ_enrolled, na.rm = TRUE),
        neet_rate = mean(lfs_neet, na.rm = TRUE),
        median_annualized_earnings = median(job_annualized_earnings_total, na.rm = TRUE),
        annualized_earnings = list(na.omit(job_annualized_earnings_total))
    )

tbl_emp |>
    reactable(
        columns = list(
            employment_rate = colDef(
                cell = function(value) {
                    scales::percent(value, accuracy = 1)
                }
            ),
            enrollment_rate = colDef(
                cell = function(value) {
                    scales::percent(value, accuracy = 1)
                }
            ),
            neet_rate = colDef(
                cell = function(value) {
                    scales::percent(value, accuracy = 1)
                }
            ),
            median_annualized_earnings = colDef(
                format = colFormat(currency = "USD", separators = TRUE)
            ),
            annualized_earnings = colDef(
                cell = function(values) {
                    sparkline(
                        values,
                        type = "box",
                        chartRangeMin = 0,
                        chartRangeMax = 2.5e5
                    )
                }
            )
        )
    )



?(caption)












1.3.5 Job Precarity
Table 1.3 summarizes the proportion of employed respondents who reported that their primary job was casual, seasonal, or temporary by inclusion group. The most common form of precarity reported is casual employment, making up 45% of primary jobs across the sample. Across each measure of precarity, social assistance recipients reported the highest rates.


Code
t_job_sat <- d_long |> 
    filter(lfs_employed) |> 
    pivot_longer(matches("^job_is_.*_primary"), names_to = "var", values_to = "val") |>
    group_by(ig_short, var) |> 
    summarize(
        p = mean(val, na.rm = TRUE)
    )


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'ig_short'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


Code
t_job_sat |> 
    pivot_wider(names_from = ig_short, values_from = p) |> 
    mutate(
        lab = case_when(
            var |> str_detect("casual") ~ "Casual", 
            var |> str_detect("seasonal") ~ "Seasonal", 
            var |> str_detect("temporary") ~ "Temporary"
        )
    ) |> 
    select(-var) |> 
    select(lab, everything()) |>  
    gt() |> 
    gtExtras::gt_theme_538() |> 
    gtExtras::gt_color_box(
        columns = c(matches("\\[")),
        domain = c(0, .9),
        scale = 100,
        suffix = "%",
        palette = c("#0000FF", "#f2f2f2", "#ff4500")
    )

1.3.7 Job Satisfaction
Table 1.5 summarizes net agreement1 with three statements concerning primary job2 satisfaction among employed respondents by inclusion group. We see evidence of higher overall job satisfaction among social assistance recipients and youth. Social assistance recipients are particularly interesting here, as they were both the most optimistic group with respect to advancement opportunities whilst also being the most concerned about job precarity. Indigenous respondents reported roughly average levels of overall satisfaction, but were by quite a wide margin the least optimistic about advancement opportunities.


Code
t_job_sat <- d_long |> 
    filter(lfs_employed) |> 
    pivot_longer(matches("^job_sat_.*_primary"), names_to = "var", values_to = "val") |>
    group_by(ig = ig_short, var) |> 
    summarize(
        net_agree = mean(as.integer(val) < 3, na.rm = TRUE) - mean(as.integer(val) > 3, na.rm = TRUE)
    )


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'ig'. You can override using the `.groups`
argument.


Code
t_job_sat |> 
    pivot_wider(names_from = ig, values_from = net_agree) |> 
    mutate(
        lab = case_when(
            var |> str_detect("advance") ~ "I have opportunities to advance", 
            var |> str_detect("overall") ~ "I am satisfied with my job", 
            var |> str_detect("precarity") ~ "I worry about losing my job"
        )
    ) |> 
    select(-var) |> 
    select(lab, everything()) |>  
    gt() |> 
    gtExtras::gt_theme_538() |> 
    gtExtras::gt_color_box(
        columns = c(matches("\\[")),
        domain = c(-.7, .7),
        scale = 100,
        palette = c("#0000FF", "#f2f2f2", "#ff4500")
    )

title: 1  Client Survey
text:
1.4 Experiences of Employment Services

1.4.1 Respondent Pathways Through Employment Services


Code
tbl_pathways <- d_long |>
    pivot_longer(
        matches("reached$"),
        names_pattern = "(.*)_reached$",
        names_to = "pathway_stage",
        values_to = "reached"
    ) |>
    mutate(
        pathway_stage = fct_relevel(
            pathway_stage,
            "engage",
            "explore",
            "progress",
            "start",
            "succeed"
        )
    ) |>
    arrange(
        pathway_stage
    ) |>
    group_by(inclusion_group, pathway_stage) |>
    summarize(
        p = mean(reached, na.rm = TRUE)
    ) |>
    mutate(
        inclusion_group = unlist(labs[inclusion_group])
    )


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'inclusion_group'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.


Code
tbl_pathways |>
    pivot_wider(names_from = pathway_stage, values_from = p) |>
    arrange(inclusion_group) |>
    reactable(
        defaultColDef = colDef(
            format = colFormat(percent = T, digits = 0)
        )
    )



?(caption)












1.4.2 Overall Satisfaction
Table 1.7 summarizes the distribution Net Promoter Scores (NPS) within each inclusion group. As measured by NPS, respondent satisfaction with employment services is quite low. In each inclusion group and in the sample overall, the proportion of respondents in the ‘Promoter’ category is lower than the proportion in the ‘Detractor’ category. The upshot is that, within and around this set of respondents, we would expect word-of-mouth to be a net negative influence on demand for employment services.
While this finding points to the existence of opportunities for improvement across the board, it is also worth noting that the distribution of NPS scores is not uniform across inclusion groups. Indigenous respondents are by far the least likely to be employment services ‘Promoters’ and the most likely to be ‘Detractors’. Individuals experiencing disability follow a similar pattern, though the difference from the sample averge (shown in the ‘Total’ row) is less pronounced.


Code
d_sat <- d_long |> 
    filter(engage_reached) |> 
    mutate(
        es_promoter = ux_nps_nps_group %in% "Promoter", 
        es_detractor = ux_nps_nps_group %in% "Detractor",
        es_nps_marginal = 100 * (es_promoter - es_detractor),
    ) |> 
    arrange(
        ig_short
    ) |> 
    mutate(
        ig_short = fct_inorder(ig_short)
    )

t_es_ovr <- d_sat |> 
    group_by(ig = inclusion_group_label) |> 
    summarize(
        nps = mean(es_nps_marginal),
        promoter = mean(es_promoter), 
        detractor = mean(es_detractor), 
    )


t_es_ovr |>
    ungroup() |> 
    gt() |> 
    gtExtras::gt_theme_538() |> 
    gtExtras::gt_color_box(
        columns = c(promoter, detractor),
        domain = c(0, 1),
        scale = 100,
        suffix = "%",
        palette = c("#0000FF", "#f2f2f2", "#ff4500")
    ) |> 
    tab_style(
        style = cell_fill(color = "gray95"), 
        locations = cells_body(
            columns = nps
        )
    ) |> 
    fmt_number(columns = nps, decimals = 0) |> 
    tab_footnote(
        "NPS is calculated as the difference between the proportion of respondents who are promoters and the proportion who are detractors."
    )

Table 1.8 shows NPS for members of each pair of inclusion groups.


Code
d_sat_xy <- d_sat |> 
    select(response_id, ig_x = ig_short, es_nps_marginal) |> 
    left_join(
        d_sat |> select(response_id, ig_y = ig_short), 
        by = "response_id",
        relationship = "many-to-many"
    ) |> 
    filter(as.integer(ig_x) > as.integer(ig_y))
    

t_es_ovr_int <- d_sat_xy |> 
    group_by(ig_x, ig_y) |> 
    summarize(
        nps = mean(es_nps_marginal),

Table 1.10 shows the full distribution of responses to holistic reflection questions within each inclusion group. The questions are designed to capture the respondent’s overall experience with employment services. The experiences about which they inquire can be broadly thought of as ‘table stakes’, meaning that they represent a kind of foundational, minimum level of service quality. It feels uncontroversial to suggest that employment services clients should always feel like they know what is happing with their cases, that each activity is productive, and that they are given a safe space in which to discuss their needs. However, among the respondents in this sample, these experiences unfortunately comprise a minority of the total.

1.4.5 Reflections on Making Progress
Table 1.13 summarizes the distribution of responses to questions about respondent experiences of codesigning and making progress in their plans for employment. These figures echo the trends observed above: newcomers, youth, and Indigenous clients disproprotionately feel that the employment services system does not communicate with them effectively, nor does it understand the goals and needs they express. Naturally, members of the same set of groups are less likely to report confidence in the effectiveness of the plan, and less likely to feel that it is responsive to their needs.


Code
tbl_progress <- d_long |>
    filter(progress_reached) |>
    pivot_longer(
        matches("^progress_reflections"),
        names_to = "var",
        values_to = "val"
    ) |>
    mutate(
        lab = unlist(labs[var]) |> str_remove("^.*? - ")
    ) |>
    filter(!is.na(val)) |>
    group_by(inclusion_group_label, lab, val) |>
    summarize(
        n = n(),
        .groups = "drop_last"
    ) |>
    mutate(
        p = n / sum(n)
    )

tbl_progress |>
    select(-n) |>
    pivot_wider(
        names_from = val,
        values_from = p
    ) |>
    group_by(lab) |>
    gt(groupname_col = "lab", rowname_col = "inclusion_group_label") |>
    gtExtras::gt_theme_538() |>
    gt::tab_style(
        style = gt::cell_text(weight = "bold"),
        locations = gt::cells_row_groups(groups = everything())

    gtExtras::gt_color_box(
        columns = 2:7,
        domain = c(0, .6),
        scale = 100,
        suffix = "%",
        palette = c("#0000FF", "#f2f2f2", "#ff4500")
    )

title: 1  Client Survey
text:
Respondents were asked to indicate their level of agreement with each prompt on a five point scale ranging from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree”. Net agreement is calculated as the difference between the proportion of respondents who agreed or strongly agreed with the statement and the proportion who disagreed or strongly disagreed.↩︎
Respondents were asked to consider their primary job, meaning the job at which they typically spend the most time working, when responding to these questions.↩︎

title: 2  Panel Survey
text:
2.1 Demographics

2.1.1 Inclusion Group Representation

    summarize(

    )

title: 2  Panel Survey
text:
2.2 Labour Force Status

2.2.1 Employment, Enrollment
Table 2.2 summarizes the labour force status of respondents by inclusion group. Most respondents (54%) were employed. Between inclusion groups, newcomers were the most likely to be employed (57%), while those receiving social assistance were understandably the least likely (42%). Youth respondents were the most likely to be enrolled in education (57%), more than double the rate observed in the full sample (26%). Indigenous respondents reported conspicuously a conspicuously low rate of employment (44%) and a high rate of NEET status (44%).

2.2.2 Job Satisfaction
Table 2.3 summarizes net agreement1 with three statements concerning primary job2 satisfaction among employed respondents by inclusion group. We see evidence of higher overall job satisfaction among social assistance recipients and youth. Social assistance recipients are particularly interesting here, as they were both the most optimistic group with respect to advancement opportunities whilst also being the most concerned about job precarity. Indigenous respondents reported roughly average levels of overall satisfaction, but were by quite a wide margin the least optimistic about advancement opportunities.

title: 2  Panel Survey
text:
2.3 Perspectives on Employment Services

2.3.1 Overview (CC-ish)
Table 2.6 summarizes respondent awareness of, engagement with, and overall reflection on employment services by inclusion group. Awareness of employment services was lowest among youth respondents (67%) and newcomers (68%), and highest among social assistance recipients (93%) and Indigenous respondents (92%). Echoing our analysis of the client survey, we see that employment services has an overall reputation that could charitably be described as ‘mediocre’, and a reputation among Indigenous clients that cannot be charitably described at all. The only inclusion group with a positive NPS (+2) is social assistance reccipients, the same group with the highest rates of awareness and engagement.
Considering this from an outreach perspective, these results suggest the following:

The ‘market’ for employment services among social assistance recipients is saturated. An overwhelming majority of this group’s members are aware of and have engaged with employment services.
A similar majority of Indigenous respondents (92%) are aware of employment services. A smaller proportion, though still a majority (64%), have engaged with them. The implication here is that simply raising awareness of the existence of employment services won’t engage more Indigenous clients. Instead, a deeper reflection on and transformation of the approach to serving Indigenous clients is needed.
Respondents with disabilities follow a similar pattern, though with a somewhat lower level of awareness, and a much less acutely negative NPS.
Youth, newcomers, and racialized individuals represent the largest untapped ‘markets’ for employment services. Raising awareness within these groups is likely to result in increased engagement, though their uniformly negative NPS scores point to opportunities for improvement in the quality of services offered.



Code

title: 2  Panel Survey
text:
Respondents were asked to indicate their level of agreement with each prompt on a five point scale ranging from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree”. Net agreement is calculated as the difference between the proportion of respondents who agreed or strongly agreed with the statement and the proportion who disagreed or strongly disagreed.↩︎
Respondents were asked to consider their primary job, meaning the job at which they typically spend the most time working, when responding to these questions.↩︎

title: 3  Staff Survey
text:
3.1 Respondent Information
Table 3.1 reports, for each inclusion group, the number of respondents who indicated that their organization serves that group and the number of organizations that set of respondents represents.
Respondents to the staff survey most commonly reported serving the Newcomer, Ontario Works, and Racialized inclusion groups. Staff at Francophone-serving organizations are the least represented in the sample.


Code
d |>
    unnest(ig_loop) |>
    filter(ig_served) |>
    group_by(ig_label) |>
    summarize(
        n = n(),
        n_org = n_distinct(id_org_short)
    ) |>
    arrange(desc(n_org)) |>
    gt() |>
    gtExtras::gt_theme_538() |>
    cols_align(columns = 1, align = "left")

?tbl-xp-staff-org reports the number and percentage of respondents by home organization. For each organization, columns [D] to [S-D] indicate whether any of the respondents from that organization “typically serve” members of each inclusion group.
The organizations represented in our sample tend to be generalists with respect to the inclusion groups they typically serve. Of the 24 organizations, staff respondents from seven indicated that they typically serve members of all 8 inclusion groups. Fred Victor was the only organization whose staff didn’t select multiple inclusion groups, though the inclusion group they did select is OW recipients. The diversity of that group suggests that FV’s staff may have interpreted the question differently than staff at other organizations.


Code
d |>
    unnest(ig_loop) |>
    group_by(ig_short, id_org_clean) |>
    summarize(
        n = n(),
        ig_served = any(ig_served),
        .groups = "drop_last"
    ) |>
    mutate(
        p = n / sum(n)
    ) |>
    pivot_wider(
        names_from = ig_short,
        values_from = ig_served
    ) |>
    arrange(desc(n)) |>
    reactable(
        defaultColDef = colDef(
            cell = function(v) {
                if (is.logical(v) && v) {
                    "\u2714\ufe0f"
                } else if (is.logical(v)) {
                    "\u274c"
                } else {
                    v
                }
            }
        ),
        columns = list(
            id_org_clean = colDef(
                header = "Organization"
            ),
            p = colDef(
                cell = function(v) {
                    scales::percent(v, accuracy = 1)
                }
            )
        )
    )



?(caption)










Table 3.2 reports the number of respondents who indicated that they serve each inclusion group, by role. At least across the generalized functional role descriptions about which we inquired, respondents tended to identify themselves as generalists, performing a variety of functions throughout their clients’ employment services journeys.

    mutate(id_role_label = labs$id_role[id_role_var]) |>
    group_by(ig_short, id_role_label) |>
    summarize(
        n = n()
    ) |>
    pivot_wider(names_from = ig_short, values_from = n) |>
    group_by(id_role_label) |>
    gt() |>

title: 3  Staff Survey
text:
3.2 Serving Inclusion Groups
Table 3.3 reports, for each inclusion group, the percentage of eligible respondents who selected each of the provided challenges when asked about the biggest challenge they face serving clients in that group. Connecting clients with employment and maintaining client engagement seem like the most challenging aspects of providing employment services. Indigenous clients seem more challenging to recruit than others. Staff serving francophones found assessing needs and developing action plans especially difficult


Code
d |>
    unnest(ig_loop) |>
    filter(ig_served, !is.na(ig_challenges)) |>
    group_by(ig_short, ig_challenges) |>
    summarize(n = n(), .groups = "drop_last") |>
    mutate(p = n / sum(n)) |>
    select(-n) |>
    pivot_wider(names_from = ig_short, values_from = p) |>
    group_by(ig_challenges) |>
    gt() |>
    gt_theme_538() |>
    tab_header(
        title = "Based on your experiences working with [X], which aspect of your role do you find the most challenging?"
    ) |>
    fmt_percent(
        columns = c(-ig_challenges),
        decimals = 0
    ) |>
    fmt_missing()

This warning is displayed once every 8 hours.

title: 3  Staff Survey
text:
3.3 Success Factors
We asked respondents about the importance of various factors in the employment success of each inclusion group. Responses were collected on a four point scale with the following options:

“Absolutely Necessary”
“Very Important”
“Somewhat Important”
“Not Important”

Table 3.8 reports, for each factor and inclusion group, the percentage of respondents who rated the factor as “Absolutely Necessary” or “Very Important”.


Code
d |>
    st_ig_tab(
        l = labs,
        var_pattern = "ig_success_factors",
        svy = "staff",
        val_transform = function(x) as.integer(x) < 3,
        title = "Based on your experiences working with [X], how important are each of the following job features to their sustainable employment?",
        subtitle = "% responding 'Absolutely Necessary' or 'Very Important'"

title: 4  Stakeholder Survey
text:
4.1 Respondent Information
Table 4.1 reports, for each inclusion group, the number of respondents who indicated that their organization serves that group and the number of organizations that set of respondents represents.


Code
d |>
    unnest(ig_loop) |>
    filter(ig_served) |>
    group_by(ig_label) |>
    summarize(
        n = n(),
        n_org = n_distinct(id_org_short)
    ) |>
    arrange(desc(n_org)) |>
    gt() |>
    gtExtras::gt_theme_538() |>
    cols_align(columns = 1, align = "left")

?tbl-xp-stakeholder-org reports the number and percentage of respondents by home organization. For each organization, columns [D] to [S-D] indicate whether any of the respondents from that organization served each inclusion group.


Code
d |>
    unnest(ig_loop) |>
    group_by(ig_short, id_org_clean) |>
    summarize(
        n = n(),
        ig_served = any(ig_served),
        .groups = "drop_last"
    ) |>
    mutate(
        p = n / sum(n)
    ) |>
    pivot_wider(
        names_from = ig_short,
        values_from = ig_served
    ) |>
    arrange(desc(n)) |>
    reactable(
        defaultColDef = colDef(
            cell = function(v) {
                if (is.logical(v) && v) {
                    "\u2714\ufe0f"
                } else if (is.logical(v)) {
                    "\u274c"
                } else {
                    v
                }
            }
        ),
        columns = list(
            id_org_clean = colDef(
                header = "Organization"
            ),
            p = colDef(
                cell = function(v) {
                    scales::percent(v, accuracy = 1)
                }
            )
        )
    )



?(caption)

    ) |>
    pivot_wider(names_from = ig_short, values_from = n) |>
    group_by(org_role_primary) |>
    gt() |>
    gt_theme_538() |>

title: 4  Stakeholder Survey
text:
4.3 Success Factors
We asked respondents about the importance of various factors in the employment success of each inclusion group. Responses were collected on a four point scale with the following options:

“Absolutely Necessary”
“Very Important”
“Somewhat Important”
“Not Important”

Table 4.5 reports, for each factor and inclusion group, the percentage of respondents who rated the factor as “Absolutely Necessary” or “Very Important”.


Code
d |>
    st_ig_tab(
        l = labs,
        var_pattern = "ig_success_factors",
        val_transform = function(x) x %in% c("Absolutely Necessary", "Very Important"),
        svy = "stakeholder",
        title = "Based on your experiences working with [X], how important are each of the following job features to their sustainable employment?",
        subtitle = "% responding 'Absolutely Necessary' or 'Very Important'"
    )
